Award.AwardTitle: UNS:A Multi-Element ICP-MS Approach for Detection of Engineered Nanoparticles in the Environment

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
#1512695
Ranville, James F.

Water, soil, and air all contain ultrafine particles, nanoparticles, that are far smaller than the width of a human hair. Nature creates nanoparticles constantly, and we may now be adding to this background of tiny particles by our development of nanotechnology. We put highly engineered nanoparticles in our medicines, foods, textiles, sunscreens, and many other products. This project seeks to use highly-developed analytical methods, along with developments in sampling of waters and sediments, to detect and quantify the nanoparticles released from nanotechnology and discriminate them from those created naturally.

This project will utilize recent developments in new nanometrologies to overcome the challenges (e.g. small size, low concentration, interfering natural NPs (NNPs)) for quantifying engineered nanoparticles (ENPs) in aquatic systems. Several new approaches to single-particle ICP-MS (spICP-MS) analysis, which have the capability to detect multiple elements on a particle-by-particle basis, will provide new data that will allow significant progress in risk assessment of nanotechnology. The analytical approach utilizes elemental composition differences, which exist between ENPs and the interfering NNPs, to provide ENP identification and quantification. The detection of multiple elements in NNPs will distinguish them from the simpler (single) element detection events characteristic of ENPs. The current "background" surface water NP concentrations (particle number, mass) and NP characteristics (e.g. size distribution, composition) will be determined. Heteroaggregation experiments, facilitated by multi-element spICP-MS analysis, will also be performed to establish how it effects the proposed nanometrologies and will also provide needed information on ENP fate in surface water. Collectively, this information is currently missing but critically important for determining the environmental health and safety effects of ENPs.

The research will be a collaboration with two established groups in research (USGS) and in public education (RiverWatch). Information acquired is expected to (i) reduce uncertainty in risk assessment of nanotechnology, (ii) provide the framework for performing ENP analysis within the USGS sampling network, with the ultimate goal of incorporating methodology from QUANT-Nano into routine water quality monitoring, (iii) through summer research experiences at CSM and field-trips we will train a diverse group of K-12 students and high school science teachers to "see the invisible" by developing simple experiments that educate about small particles in water. We will involve these students and educators in the monitoring of their local water resources, and (iv) educate the public on the importance of environmental monitoring to facilitate safe development of nanotechnology,

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project (NSF-CBET grant 1512695) involved laboratory research, graduate student training, and public outreach, and was designed to help evaluate the impacts of the nanotechnology revolution by improving our ability to measure nanoparticles in the aquatic environment. Nanotechnology has the promise of making new products that are useful to society by harnessing the special chemical properties of materials when they are created in the nanometer (10^-9 meter) size range.  This small size is illustrated in Image 1, which shows that on a relative scale, the moon is as many times larger than a tennis ball as the tennis ball is larger than a nanoparticle (NP).  We call these laboratory-prepared materials engineered nanoparticles (ENPs).  The major goal of the project was to improve our ability to measure ENPs after they enter the environment, one such means of entry to the environment being through wastewater treatment plants. There are many challenges in making this measurement, perhaps the greatest being the fact that nature makes NP through processes such as erosion of soils by water and wind.  Thus, any sample taken from a natural water, such as a stream, contains these natural NPs (NNPs) as well (Image 1).  Human activities can also inadvertently create NPs, which we call incidental NPs (INPs).  Two examples are the burning of coal and the wearing down of tires, which release NPs into the air and water respectively.

We developed a method that can measure the elemental composition of each individual NP in a water sample at a speed fast enough to analyze thousands of NPs per minute.  The method uses Inductively Coupled Plasma-Mass Spectrometry (ICP-MS) and rapidly measures NP compositions one particle at a time.  The unique aspect of this project was to develop new methods that are capable of measuring multiple elements within the same NP.  Prior to this project only one element could be measured in each NP.  This new, multi-element, capability allows us to generate a "chemical fingerprint" for each NP sampled.  With this fingerprint, future studies will be able to investigate the relative amounts of each of the three NP types present in the aquatic environment.  While the goal of the project was to improve our ability to examine how nanotechnology might lead to the release of ENPs, with possible harmful effects on the environment, the developed methods can also help geoscientists understand how the natural environment works, including examining how climate change may affect processes that involve NNPs and INPs.  To this end we published a review article in the journal Science to outline our thoughts on the field of Nanogeoscience.

The project partially supported three graduate students (two have graduated with PhDs) and one minority undergraduate student (BS in chemistry) at the Colorado School of Mines.  The professional development of the students was facilitated through the process of presenting  their research findings at university and professional meetings, as well as preparing research articles for scientific journals.  This project also fostered a collaboration with two new assistant professors at external universities, although they did not receive any NSF financial support.   The research included our studies of natural systems, where NNPs were fingerprinted by their composition of the elements (Al, Si, Fe) commonly found in minerals (Image 2).  We also examined the element titanium, which is often added to concrete and sunscreen as an ENP.  Finally, we also examined zinc-containing NPs in an urban river as a means to examine INPs that may be a results of tire wear (Image 2).

As part of the project, we communicated our results to the scientific community and the general public in a manner of ways.  In 2016 the project PI hosted the 11th International Conference on the Environmental Impacts of Nanoparticles and Nanomaterials (Nano2016), which brought together more than 200 participants.  In every summer, over the duration of the project, the PI taught a one-week course on environmental chemistry to the Chemistry majors at Colorado School of Mines (average enrollment is 20 students/year).  The course incorporated the NP characterization methods developed in this project.  In 2020 the PI presented a webinar to Golden United, a local community group, on the topic of NPs that result from recreational activities in Clear Creek, a stream that flows through the city of Golden.  The methods we have developed will provide a key analytical capability for other researchers to move forward to better understand the natural, and human-altered, nanogeochemical environment.
